Nile red (also known as Nile blue oxazone) is a lipophilic stain. Nile red stains intracellular lipid droplets yellow. In most polar solvents, Nile red will not fluoresce; however, when in a lipid-rich environment, it can be intensely fluorescent, with varying colours from deep red (for polar membrane lipid) to strong yellow-gold emission (for neutral lipid in intracellular storages). The dye is highly solvatochromic and its emission and excitation wavelength both shift depending on solvent polarity[1] and in polar media will hardly fluoresce at all.[2]

Nile red has applications in cell biology, where it can be used as a membrane dye which can be readily visualized using an epifluorescence microscope with excitation and emission wavelengths usually shared with red fluorescent protein. Nile red has also been used as part of a sensitive detection process for microplastics in bottled water.[3][4] Additionally, nile red is a remarkable candidator in fabricating membrane for different sensors to detect environmental changes, such as taste, gas, pH, etc.[5]

In triglycerides (a neutral lipid), Nile red has an excitation maximum of about 515 nm (green), and emission maximum of about 585 nm (yellow-orange).[6] In contrast, in phospholipids (polar lipids), Nile red has an excitation maximum of about 554 nm (green), and an emission maximum of about 638 nm (red).[7]

Synthesis
Nile red can be prepared through acid hydrolysis by boiling a solution of Nile blue with sulfuric acid.[8] This process replaces an iminium group with a carbonyl group. Alternatively, Nile red and its analogs (naphthooxazine dyes) can be prepared by acid-catalyzed condensation of corresponding 5-(dialkylamino)-2-nitrosophenols with 2-naphthol. The yields are generally moderate as no co-oxidant is used in this procedure.[9] Since the reaction to generate Nile red does not usually completely exhaust the supply of Nile blue, additional separation steps are required if pure Nile red is needed.

Your setup is awesome, but unfortunately you could get arrested in my homeland.
Things you could not get:
- Place without running water
- Electricity would never pass
- You have to ask for permission for having some chemicals and you have a government check at least every 3 years.
- Fume hood (requires a little bit more filtration).
- Ikea is not lab-certified and you are not legally allowed to use it in lab.
- This ceiling is not allowed in many less-hazardous places. You could use it only in not-long-occupied meeting rooms due to fire and gas hazards.
- Also chemicals shown in the video require special permit and regular government checks unless you are a big company. If you have any cyanide in a lab, there are required checks. If you are a big company owned by our prime minister, you can freely dispose many tons of it into a river without anyone to finish the investigation.

Lovely fume cupboard. As far as large quantities of oxides of nitrogen are concerned, the company I used to work for did similar stuff to that at night so, at three o'clock in morning, the air in your neighbourhood turns a sort of orange colour until it disperses and nobody notices. ;-)


One thing you need to consider is that the two rooms are in effect a confined space so things like a Kipps apparatus in the fume cupboard is a no no because people have power cuts and at the level of toxicity of H2S, you cannot afford to walk into a room at the beginning of the day and take a lung full of the stuff. Also, I have seen people doing pretty stupid things on YouTube wth liquid nitrogen and liquid oxygen and again, thinking of confined spaces, with N2, you can take the O2 well down below 21% to a level that cannot support life and with O2, take above around 25% and fires get difficult to put out. Then there is handling things like that where forearm length gloves or latex gloves are totally inadequate as are goggles - you need a chemical suit and a full-face visor if you are going to use them reasonably safely and preferably outside, not indoors.

NileRed,.... CARBON. Put it in the microwave. How can I measure the temp of that plasma? GRAPHENE OXIDE. Before you microwave it, test on a styrofoam boat in water for diamagnetic or magnetic. After microwaving it becomes super paramagnetic, but why? After you make your graphene oxide, (electrolisys of graphite (+) and platinum plated Titanium mesh (-) @ 10-12volts for approx 3 days. Also for every gallon of distilled water, add 50 grams of potassium sulphate, (sulphate of potash) for your electrolyte. car battery charger works well for power supply. Do this in a 5 gallon bucket with you cathode and anode dropped in from the top, though the lid for the 5 gallon bucket, secured and made air-tight with hot glue. If you have a submersible water pump, (the kind you can buy at the hardware store for small garden fountains), it greatly increases the yield of the GO, (graphene oxide). After 3 days reaction, take a torch to the surface of the water, while your pump is still circulating water.... you should see that GO will actually swim to the flame even against the current! This I cannot explain. Now remove your electrodes, turn off your pump, let the water settle so that there no more current. tie a torus N54 neodymium magnet to a piece of string and hang from a bar across the bucket so that half the magnet is submerged. Now look closely at the GO around the magnet. This is not an air battery because the bucke is not metal. This "perpetual movment of the GO too cannot be explained, unless this is some form of room temperature super conductivity, which I tend to believe it may be, due to another experiment that backs this up. That experiment is the 3D printing of a geometric lattice that gets coated with GO. When the lattice is charged briefly with a 9 volt battery, the lattice hold a small, (0.10 volt) charge until the lattice is grounded). If you have the time, I would like you to verify my findings. Ive asked no one to do this yet, but I assure you I have verified hundreds of times my self. One last piece of information... IBM, Intel and others have been trying to figure out how to use graphene as the replacement for silicone to manufacture computer processors. The difficulty is that Graphene can not be made act as a transistor, because the only way to turn the transistor, (switch) on and off is to do so physically... that is until you microwave it. Ive open sourced this and even wrote to their engineers, but strangely no response. You did ask for some suggestions and I have a couple for your thoughts and honestly the comment posted are pretty good. I have a couple;
*Extinguisher(s)??? YESTERDAY! please do it. Have a CO2 type handy, they're more cost but cause less cleanup damage
*Implement class system for your storage (oxiders, flammables, poisons, etc.) with labels on the cabinets. Print on coloured paper and tape them on. You know the drill, just like institution labs (well most). Also have a very detailed and up to date chemical inventory list.

Strange you don't have water (as most places have washrooms) but if you are in a commercial zone you will be subject the all the usual conditions. I am Canadian as well so I am familiar with Provincial , regional codes, fire codes. Once you are known the flags go up and you will be inspected from some branch of your local officialdom. to be honest it's a bit late for suggestions considering you've already set so much up. i've built a lab for myself on a similar scale about 3 times now so here are a few tips.

first suggestion is get a reverse osmosis machine for de-ionized water production, the 75-100gal/day ones are pretty cheep. make sure to keep a nice high rejection ratio. (i understand you don't have running water on-site for now, but you can run the RO at home and bring the water in). once you stop washing glassware with tap water you will never go back.

an air filter makes more of a difference to experiment reliability than you would think. less dust means everything from weighing to decomposition is more consistent. a good example is that i can store 12% peroxide open in an unfiltered room for maybe a day tops, but can leave it in a filtered one for over a week. there are however some reactions which will ONLY happen when there is sufficient dust, i find that dandruf is a suitable substitute in most cases. .

wrap every chemical container with way to much parafilm, there are many reasons for this but it becomes exponentially more important the more different samples you have in proximity to one another. in 20 years when you'r looking at your old bottles wondering if it's permanganate or iodine, you'l be glad you can still read the labels. it helps contain smashed glass containers to which has saved me from long hazardous cleanups many times.

things are just what they are made of, so most lab gear is WAY overpriced, a home made fume hood hood is cheep, easy and often more chemically resilient than a brand made one. a hood can get pretty beat up and it's hard to get every last trace of some compounds out of there, so i like to replace parts every few months. i mostly use RTV silicon as the sealant as it's chemically resistant, airtight and you can take it off easily with a razor blade. you can build a scrubber to go before your exhaust to give yourself a bit more flexibility on what you can do

lastly a note on safety gear.

POWDER fire extinguisher. just do it, don't let your dreams be dreams.

an eye bath is nice but you can squirt saline into your eyes from the standard opticians bottles easily enough that it's optional.

a shower however, is; in my opinion, an absolute must when working above test tube scale with anything more dangerous than say 10% acetic. if you'r distilling hardware sulfuric without a shower then may figurative god help you if it super-heats and goes pop.

a nice tub of sodium bicarbonate in easy reach. as it can neutralize both acids and strong bases you can just chuck it on anything if you'r unsure what to do (there are some rare incompatibilities so use common sense). due to bicarb being so cheep i use it like i would a bucket of sand if theirs a fire.

some Plexiglas glued to a stand as a blast/spatter screen comes in handy.

ps: i'l probably be posting some videos to you-tube once i have a backlog of 10 episodes and i finish editing.

When working with something you can't vent to the outside, try to contain it then react and/or recover it.
An example for chlorine gas:
Produce hydrogen through splitting water, or just buy it. When a reaction is going to produce chlorine gas you can either close off the reaction vessel or build and set up a mini fume hood. Either would lead to a sealed container where you would add an excess of hydrogen. In the presence of UV radiation from an open window and direct sunlight or full spectrum UV lights, this will form Hydrogen Chloride that could be bubbled through water to produce Muriatic Acid.

N02 is even easier, just bubble it directly into water.

For added protection, run two blubbers into the bottom of a glass chamber, fill with water about 3/4 full and seal the top. one will be attached to your experiment, the other will be attached to the top of the chamber with a small air pump to recirculate the gases in the chamber until it has all been consumed by the water.

I left a similar comment on the original upload but since it's safety-related and a chance to help public awareness, I'll put one up again. I work in chemical industries and the current GHS safety standards for labeling require several items be present (all of them will be found in the first 2 sections of the chemical's SDS):
-The identity of the chemical
-any pictograms describing related to the chemical/physical hazards it presents
-a signal word, if indicated (Will either be Warning or DANGER)
-All Hazard Statements
-Any applicable Precautionary Statements (this will usually be all Precautionary Statements unless small container size limits space/readability)
-the name and address of the manufacturer
The pictograms should be red with black borders, the signal word should be red, and the text size should be large enough to be easily readable.

Re: Your thoughts on doing You Tube videos being weird

I have some perspective to share. I'm an 80's era kid, and am largely self taught in most things I do for my own pleasure and professionally. College rounded that out some, and wasn't the investment it is for people today.

Back then, taking one's own path was more of an outlier. Like you, I tend to enjoy learning and sharing what I learn, and often have that outlet professionally.

To explain that, I grew up at the end of what I will characterize as a, "learn and do to solve problems" type culture. My many antics learning about technology, science, and other things as a kid were rewarded back then. People encouraged it, and I found many opportunities to apply what I learned to help others, make date money, and generally get started. Honestly, that was more of an outlier type way to navigate life back then. The trend was toward a "spend to solve or do" culture. That didn't work for me, but it did for most of my peers.

One of the reasons for that was it being hard. Information access largely consisted of going to a library and doing a lot of reading, and figuring out how to get to talk to people with experience.

Over the last decade, I've seen our access to information change things considerably. Anyone with an interest, passion, can find out pretty much all they need to know online. Given a mentor, group, or even just focus and some resolve, it is possible to reach considerable mastery, and increasing numbers of people do.

Honestly, your decisions and feelings about all of this make a great deal of sense.

This trend toward people learning, doing, making, experimenting, is on the rise, and you are in resonance with all of that. Many of the expectations set for us, tend to clash with hard realities these days. It is also a lot more important to manage one's burdens and the requirements associated with them as, for many people, risk reward propositions are more aggressive than they have been in the past.

The world is growing complex. And for many, too many I feel, it's also quite expensive. Flat out, it's much harder for most people to make a good living, and this has forced changes in life expectations that resonate with the work you, and many others, are doing.

Not only do we have insane information access, many people can get the things they need shipped to them, often at a very reasonable cost.

My 2 cents:
You need ventilation in that acid cabinet. It’s going to rust out the entire cabinet over time, even with the containers closed. A plastic acid cabinet would work better, even if you don’t have ventilation (which I strongly support installing).
Separate your oxidizers. I can appreciate them being in an explosion proof fridge, but you shouldn’t store the oxidizers with flammables. I would even go so far as to say you should keep the nitric in its own storage.
Label your cabinets. Keep an accurate chemical inventory. Not sure how it works in your neck of the woods, but label your chemicals with their associated hazards if they are in secondary containers. Local fire department will appreciate the inventory it if it is ever needed (among other reasons).
Someone else already addressed the emergency eye wash problem. While I hope you never need it, it’s important that it’s readily available.

I look forward to whatever you post next!

I have a few things to add to your glass ware drawers: Try to store everything perpendicular to the direction you're pulling. This way you can minimize the risk of your glassware breaking. You should also add some packing flakes, or styrofoam pellets. This will also reduce the risk of breaking and it will reduce the noise the drawers produce. And lastly I would suggest that you label your drawers. You maybe don't need it because you know the location for everything but it looks much more professional.

In my home lab, I organize by Baker color code.
Each container has a bit of colored tape on it, and there's a separate shelf for each color.

Green = general storage
Red = flammable
Blue = toxic
Yellow = oxidizer/reactive
White = corrosive
Striped = stored seperately.

Info on this system can be found online.

Hi nile, first of all thank you for all the effort that you have put into the making of this lab. I plan to become a patreon as soon as I get some revenues whatsoever. You totally deserve it.
Secondarily I've got some questions for you.
1)Are you gonna protect your fumehood in some way? Because metal doesn't behave well with a lot of chemicals that you use.
2)Do you plan to install a vacuum pump and nitrogen in your fumehood? Because this would cost something like 1000-1200 additional dollars, but it would increase so much the range of your possible experiments. Even suzuki couplings for example.
Of course you have spent a lot of money on this project, and your lab is already awesome, so this is totally optional.
Also, I would recommend installing running water into your fumehood. I mean putting water in the cupboard below, cuz if you'll have to refrigerate something having water tubes all across your lab isn't going to be fun.
Hope this wasn't too long to read, thank you again :)

If you look into travel trailer parts they have a trigger that turns on the pump when you turn on the tap. You can get a cheap counter-top bottled water holder with a cold and hot water tanks. $50-60 Take it apart and install the tanks under the sink for hot and cold water. Run the hose under the counter through the water tanks to the tap then you don't need a pump but it's nice to have the pressure.

Lucky bugger. It is hard to get lab work here, even with a degree. The PhD folk snap them up much easier and I was forced into home lab, to practice my passion, skills etc. However the negative attention from ignorant “family - thought I was up to no good” and I had been raided by police/HazMat in full chemical suits (LOl), where everything that I had manufactured/collected over a long period of time was confiscated without any charges. Not to mention the immense embarrassment from the attention of equally ignorant neighbours who were evacuated or saw everything happening. The most dangerous thing I ever made was about 0.5 g of nitrocellulose, which was placed into a bomb disposal trailer and detonated at a police disposal range (Was on the Australian TV show The Force - 2013). Absolute joke and an embarrassment to myself and to the psyche of our general public/police who stated that I was randomly mixing dangerous chemicals together. Home Chemistry = meth lab or terrorist bomb making.... Not possibly a hobby?
